Man, I've been fighting spiders with potion effects, and I was thinking, "It would be cool to breed spiders, or tame them." It just sounds like a good idea. They could be bred during the day, or in bright areas. Spiders that you breed should probably become passive over a span of three (in-game) days. All offspring should be fully passive and tamable, and once grown, rideable. [Initial Idea]

However, tamed spiders may become more useful than tamed horses. Spiders can climb walls, attack enemies, and spawn in with passive potion effects, allowing for selective breeding for far better enhanced spiders. These all culminate into reasons horses and possibly dogs may become obsolete. Spiders are extremely common, and easily farmable. Taming spiders may make two mobs redundant, and make an extremely overpowered passive mob. [Cons]

So, this means the spiders riding/loyalty may need to be gimmicky. Maybe during the night (or reverse) they attack or kick you off, and maybe require meat to keep them passive. Perhaps you need something to remind you that they are still a hostile mob, even if leashed. Just trying to brain storm the idea, and possible flaws. [Possible Fixes]
this is a good idea but lets take out the riding part

I always am in favor of interesting ways to have magic and potion things in minecraft. Maybe a potion being required for spider taming would be cool. I am uncertain of riding, but having a spider follow you similar to a wolf would be cool. I would love to have cave spiders following me, would be really cool.

Please no spider jockeys, that would ruin this game and give it a cheesy fake kind of vibe imo. The polar bear and the beast thing is one thing but you have to keep it in the realm of believability even for fantasy.

Hi!
Can you give us more details
The morph mod is cool and all but there is a reason it is a mod. It does not fit with the current style and balance of vanilla Minecraft. Absolutely no support from me on this one.

A quick helpful note: if you're posting about a mod, it may also help to explain what it does so people don't need to search for it. This has the added benefit of explaining what parts of it you are specifically asking for.

Thanks for your contribution!
I think morphing is a good idea, but how do you make that balanced?

The mod without abilities and including the (usually) reduced health of the target mob would be decently balanced.  Especially if the max health can only be reduced.  What makes the mod OP is when you can morph into a bat and have flight.

It would be convenient to be able to morph into a one high thing and move around small spaces, especially for redstoners.  However, this same functionality could be achieved by adding the ability to crawl.  After all, who can't figure out how to fit under a one meter high table?

I feel morphing to be far too far flung and broken a concept for even a new type of magic system in Minecraft. However it would make for an interesting command prompt, especially if extended to allow for mobs to be converted into different types of mobs. The only exception being boss monsters such as the Wither Demon and Ender Dragon.

for example:

/morph @e[type=pig] Creeper OR /morph @p Chicken
Exactly I would LOVE to have morph in Minecraft! It would be nice to actually be able to play hide and seek without digging a hole a covering it up again

add it for chickens too

I like the idea of leeches, but I would put forward a couple of slight changes in the suggested game mechanics:

- they spawn in both swamps and rivers in clumps of 4-16 (or whatever)

- they are like skinny black silverfish and sit on blocks at the bottom of the body of water; when you are within 3 blocks on the same Y, they will all release and swarm towards you.

- they latch onto one location (arms x2, legs x2, back/torso) and can't latch on if there is another one there. (They just randomly swim around you waiting to get an opportunity to latch on.)

- after X ticks they drain 1/2 heart and drop off.

- X would depend on armor at that location.

- If you have a potion effect, it ends when you take leech damage.

- they all drop off whenever you take non-leech damage.

- dropped leeches will become fat (like silverfish) and half speed. They will drop to the bottom of the water block and rest for X ticks until they become skinny again and ready to feed... perhaps this is a breeding cycle and that leech splits onto an adjacent source block when it becomes skinny.

- they don't do well out of water and will just take damage/die when they drop off in air.
I feel if it also drop leech teeth (they make weapons stronger when you add them to weapon) it would be a bunch cool I still voted thou
they should do 6 damage of health bar I love the idea it would make it perfect edition

Yes Minecraft really needs a parasite right now

I think this should be a thing just like the tadpoles. But maybe instead, they aren’t visible, but if you’re in the swamp water too long you suddenly get an effect that literally says “Leeches” and damages you half a heart each second.
Or maybe they are visible like tadpoles. Or maybe they’re not visible but the water is different, and can maybe even be bucketed. Or maybe when bucketed the water turns to normal water, and it’s only leeched if in swamp. Probably best option.

I like the idea of leeches being used in potions because it parallels the use of leeches in medieval medicine. I feel like leeches could be used for a specific purpose themselves, though, like maybe leeches sap your energy while removing status effects from you? Like you could use leeches to un-poison yourself when poisoned but it will take away hunger and slow your movement. Also maybe, similar to the Bucket of Axolotl and other mobs that can be put in buckets, there should be a Bottle of Leeches?
I also really like the idea of there being a reason to navigate more carefully through the swamps. Instead of splashing willy nilly through the water, you'd have a reason to stay on land.

Hello everyone, I made this post almost 3 years ago but on a different account. Back then I was thinking rhinos would be a great addition to minecraft's savanna biomes but now when I think of it it was actually not a good idea. As you may know rhinoceros as a species is very endangered (and yes I know, so are polar bears but they have already been a part of the game for 5 years now), so much that they are on brink of extinction.
So my opinion is that they shouldn't be added for the same reason sharks were never added, to avoid encouraging people killing them or getting anywhere near them.

They can be fire resistant and gallop through the lava, but standing, they begin to sink.

What if a few Piglins could spawn around them/ riding them, and these groups would spawn near you at random in the nether, like those small Pillager raiding parties that give you the bad omen effect. Killing the hostile Piglins without killing the horses will let you try to tame the leftover horses.

Abilities of the Wither Skeleton Horse

 It has fire resistance, can run fast on top of soul sand and soul soil, has significantly more health compared to the regular skeleton horses, and maybe will have glowing blue eyes every time it sets foot on soul sand or soul soil (design inspired by SystemZee's video). Moreover, once tamed, it will attack any mob that either attacks or is attacked by the player, using some sort of charging move, causing some serious knock back and wither effect to the mob (note that it has a cooldown). It does this either while the player is off the horse or when the player is moving towards the target mob.

Acquiring A Wither Skeleton Horse

While exploring the Soul sand valley biome, a lone wither skeleton horse can be spotted, this is the wither skeleton horse trap (note that unlike the ones in the overworld, this one does not require any natural event to spawn, it is just a very rare spawn). Once the player gets near the horse, it will charge at the player till the player is hit, causing the player to be knocked back. This first charge will cause an explosion, in which its rider will spawn along with 2 normal skeleton horses with normal skeletons riding them. The rider of the wither skeleton horse will be a wither skeleton, holding a netherite sword. The wither skeleton horse will also charge at the player at this phase. To tame it, the player must defeat the riders.
They'd probably work exactly like regular skeleton horses, but with maybe fire resistance.

I loved the fact that you added the possibility of dyeing the wolf's armor. Regarding the painting issue, I think it would be interesting if it occurred on the entire armor, changing the main color. I wish they changed the wolf AI a little. I went to the trial chambers with a friend of mine, and our wolves attacked each other more than they helped in PVP, and they never stopped attacking each other, until they both died

It would be interesting to have some way for the player to not be able to kill his wolf during PVP and PVE. Many times, I end up accidentally hitting my own wolf, increasing the chance of it dying. It could happen like with Allay, where I couldn't attack my own wolf while it attacks something or someone

There is an issue in Minecraft where your wolf may stay behind and never teleport to you again. It would be interesting if there was a "whistle" in the game, which immediately calls your pets to you. This way, you would never lose your wolf and your cats in an unfamiliar place again. You could take advantage of those excluded copper horns to take on this function

It would be interesting if when you sit your wolf down, it doesn't attack again when it gets up again. It's horrible when I hit a friend of mine, and my wolf keeps attacking him, until one of them dies

It would be interesting if the lava damage hit the armored wolf much less. Due to errors in the AI, your wolf may throw itself into a pit of lava when facing a mob in the nether, and thus die. As a way to prevent this, lava, in particular, could do much less damage
It would be interesting if other players couldn't take your wolf's armor off. Enemies could use this to easily disarm the pet and kill it faster
If you're not going to color the entire armor when it's dyed, some details in the colored area would be interesting.

If the wolf’s health would run out before it’s armor would break, food would still be useful and the wolf armor would feel more congruent with player armor.

The system of the wolf not taking damage until the armor breaks is very creative. Can you keep this please?

The new changes are well considered and add lots of value for players who travel with wolf companions! The amount of protection (plus the previous increase to wolf HP) feels effective and well-balanced, and I wouldn't want the protection to be any higher.

Communicating the armour's durability is very effective, by emitting particles when taking significant damage and through visual texture changes. However, the inconsistent durability threshold for each damage stage is less intuitive (the texture changes after the first 4 durability points, then the next 16, then the next 24, then breaking after the last 20). I like that the pristine state displays even if the durability is not quite full - this is convenient - but after that, a more even split (4, then 20, 20 and 20) would be more intuitive. Alternatively, there could be one less state, with the final change later on (such as changing at 4, then 30 (or 40), and breaking after 30 (or 20) more) to make it more obvious when the armour needs urgent repair.

Some of the player concerns about improving wolf survivability are not related to their personal defense, though - wolves can still put themselves in lethal danger (usually to natural hazards like lava or long falls) due to issues with their pathfinding algorithms, so I hope to see pet pathfinding improvements in future :)
You updated the wolf armor so beautifully.... Can you do something similar with the horses please?

This is really cool, but honestly, the texture of the painted armor looks a bit odd. Overall, I think it wouldn't be bad if wolf armor could have blacksmith patterns applied to it instead of being painted. I have some more ideas, but they're quite controversial:

It would work the same way as with regular human equipment, but I understand it's quite expensive, so each material (gold, diamonds, netherite, etc.) would give different effects to wolves - for example, gold, which is very common in hot biomes, would give the dog less fire damage. I think my idea is clear, but if you don't like this option, I have another one, which is a bit silly.

Excellent update! Wolf armor is finally useful against creepers, lava, fall damage etc. It's great that we can now dye it, I'm glad mojang listens to the community.

Having said that, the low durability heal of each scute is bad, constantly repairing the armor makes adventure with wolves annoying. One scute needs to heal at least half durability. Better yet, when durability is completely gone, it should still be usable as a "broken wolf armor", giving some defense for the wolves instead, just like before. This way, players don't have to always carry stacks of scutes. Ideally it needs a regen enchant.

On multiplayer, wolves should reset their attack AI via sitting, because if you accidentally hit a friend, the wolf will permanently target them until it dies. For PvP, wolf armor is balanced & not OP, as you can bypass them with thorns, harming pots, shears.

I also love the Bogged as it makes swamps & some caves unique! The SE can be slimier & different from skeletons. I like it can be sheared, but obscure mechanics need achievements to hint at players (Also, husks should really drop renewable sands). Future hostile mobs should not be reskins, we need uniques like fishes, arthropods.

The lesser Bogged HP/firerate makes it manageable on easy/normal mode, which is nice for casual players, but I hope the poison's more challenging on hard mode.

I like how hardcore's coming to bedrock! I hope I can convert my current world to hardcore & I wish multiplayer hardcore's possible.
I would like to see a message in chat when my wolf’s armor breaks! Thanks!
How about Armadillo Scute Pet Armor instead of specifically Wolf Armor?

I see one problem. WOLF armor and HORSE armor. It’s impractical to have special armor for only one type of mob. These armors would be more accepted if they were PET Armor and MOUNT armor. Versatility is key here.

Most of these changes to the wolf armor are interesting. I think "pets" overall as a concept are kinda flawed from the top down which makes this armor interesting but just not that fun to use.

I think several questions arise here.
Why are we so opposed to a UI? Interactions such as clicking a horse with a saddle or armor, equipping those items is incredibly fun. But the interaction for repairing dog armor is rough. The sit hitbox is much smaller, and hard to interact with. I would have a UI window open when you click the wolves head. Have a slot for armor for the wolf, and allow for repairs to be done using the anvil workstation.

Why are there so many darn armadillo scutes? No cooldown of sweeping them off. Right click the all powerful wolf armor and tada never fear your dog is immortal. 


The Wolf Ai Problem:
Essentially the main problem with the wolf is its AI. While I would be okay without a UI to apply armor like the horse, its a shame that the actual pet AI with the wolf is so lackluster. The wolf tends to wander into danger constantly and deals damage (mostly to other players and their pets in multiplayer).

Wolves are the only creature and "true pet" in Minecraft. There are no taming interactions, besides cats, that grant you a devoted protector. The fox has a unique ability to pickup items, sniffers find cosmetic plants. The two skills of a dog- the snoot and the fetch, taken by these two untamable creatures :(

Going against requests to add enchantments to wolf armor, I don't see the point in applying some enchantments as repair, since wolf armor has a system in which it breaks, And only then does the wolf begin to take damage. It wouldn't even be viable to add armor repair
Wolf beds could be used to teleport your wolf back to you when you click on them. This way, you would never lose your wolves again

1.21 is looking good as it caters to combat players, explorers, redstoners, pet lovers, builders etc. Many Youtubers enjoy having these pet features in Minecraft, as well as chambers adding gameplay content. I think the few flaws left is the chambers; Breeze charges are items you need tons of, for parkour content & jumping mountains etc, but atm it needs to be farmed slowly, making it very useless. It needs to be craftable into a reusable weapon instead, it'll really satisfy combat and exploration players! Often, mojang additions are unfortunately made less fun/viable for the sake of simplicity/consistency, such as copper bulb ticks which could revolutionize redstone, but it's now gone. Content should ideally generate some hype to entice new & old players to come back.

After testing the latest updates more, I love the wolf pack-size variety, and the savanna types that spawn 4-8 packs can really make minecraft worlds feel alive! (Though sometimes you actually want the lonely scary vibe in certain areas, which is why backrooms mods in MC are so popular)

Still, traveling companions add so much incentive to play minecraft. It definitely would be nice if we can upgrade our companions, because back then the most convenient and effective way to use wolves was to not heal them and keep breeding. They felt like disposable soldiers. But with wolf armor enchants using valuable books, each wolf will feel more valuable and it'll encourage players to build a connection with them.

I am very glad that the team finally decided to give our beloved Canine Companion the care they deserved after all these years. And so far personally I do think that protection and customizability do play a huge role in making our companion better and safer. However, I would like to add some simple but crucial changes to the wolf logic which does have a huge impact on their reliablity, as I have been studying them for some time already.
1. Their Leap-to-Attack Logic: As the current implementation, the wolf occasionally leaps at the target when they reach a certain distance closer to the target. However, this logic doesn't check whether the target is in a dangerous area or not, causing wolves to very often, follow their target down hazardous areas (e.g. lava). This can be improved by reducing the jump distance and adding additional checks if the target is in hazard.
2. Their max-distance fall tolerate: As per the current implementation when the target runs and falls down from a high platform, the wolf keeps on pursuing the target and path to the open spot, falling to its own death. This can be improved by forcing the wolf's pathfinder to not tolerate path points that are more than 3-4 blocks lower the previous path points and forcefully making the wolf discard the target if the target falls more than 4 - 5 blocks.
3. The wolf should discard the target and teleport back to the owner while it is fighting when it is more than a certain distance away from the owner.

How I would implement crows:

1. They attack wheat only at it's first and last stages of growth (eating the seeds/ripe grain) when they attack it at it's final stage of growth, it reverts back to it's previous stage of growth.

2. They also attack any seeds (only first growth stage)

3. They are scared of Jack o lanterns and snow golems that have jack o lanterns on their heads.

4. They may also attack parrots & any other small birds that are added (ie.pidgeons) if there is no grain to eat... as well as bees. They always attack silverfish. 

5. they spawn at night and are neutral towards the player.

6.  If fed regularly, (bread, seeds, or meat, they share bread/meat with other crows) they and their flock and their children will be "tamed" and will follow the player around, not eat their wheat or hunt nearby birds (because they are well fed)

7. If you hurt them or if they see you hurt another crow (unprovoked), they, their flock, their children and any crows they come across will lose their "tamed" status... and if they don't have the tamed status, become hostile to you... & alert other mobs to your presence... meaning zombies will spawn more reinforcements. (also, crows DO NOT forget... they pass on intergenerational trauma... much like humans)

8. They occasionally pick up items (especially shiny ones)

9. you can bring your trust level back up by being around crows & not hurting them.

10. They occasionally interact with blocks (like looking into pots, picking at wheat blocks/grass, etc.)

In addition to your points, it would allow wild-spaces to feel more alive, even after you've already captured the existing farm animals. (To this end, perhaps the spawning conditions should be slightly more complicated than just sky-lit grass?)

I agree with deer specifically, partly because:

  • the same model could be used in basically every biome, with only texture and size variation, because there is some deer-like ungulate in basically every habitat on earth
  • they are relatable to a global audience (see above)
  • deer are the animal best associated with hunting (at least in NA)

Biome Suggestions:

  • Caribou &/or Moose in Tundras, Taigas and Wooded Mountains
  • White-Tail in Plains & Forests
  • Gazelle in Deserts
  • Antelope in Savannahs
  • Pronghorn in Badlands
  • Marsh Deer in Swamps
  • Brocket or Muntjac in Jungles

The whole point of glowing mushrooms is to further customize our bases, not as an alternative to the brighter light sources. They would only be cliché if introduced as limited color(s) or found part of naturally generation. We should be able to use a glow potion & dye to decide for ourselves what color the brown  mushrooms we plant will glow as in a low to mid light. There should be 11 colors, no Black, no grey(s), no white, & no brown. I don't think Mojang will program the Sniffer to randomly find 1 of 11 colors. Farming them would be a pain. Its a pain that the most variety for RTX are among the brightest blocks, & the low & mid light sources don't have as much.

I think the idea of the sniffer having different plants to find from all the different kinds of blocks would definitely be cool. Like a different one for mycelium, grass, dirt, podzol, sand, maybe even snowy grass.
it would be better from something like glow lichen
